text: The National Anthem resounds over the precision maneuvers the Navy’s Blue Angels. When Old Glory fills the frame th local announcer identifies the station, signifies the megahertz and signs off for the morning. Transmission end and a BLAST of disturbing static rules the airwaves. It i 2:30am on a Sunday morning.

The TV set appears. A fireplace is off to the right, trop of outstanding achievement in annual home sales on the mantel; STEVEN FREELING asleep in his convertible chair, open briefcase on his lap, real estate maps and lease contracts spread out on the floor by his stocking feet. CAMERA CONTINUES TO WITHDRAW until we are moving out of t living room of this suburban two-story home and up the stairs.

CAMERA MOVES along the hallway, past the guest bath and o to a partially open door. We explore this room, if only f an instant, to catch DIANE FREELING, 32, tossing in her sleep, a tangle of hair covering her face. INT. DANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 3 CAMERA moves away and slithers into another bedroom. DIAN FREELING is sixteen, very beautiful, and snoring unevenly She is surrounded by potato chips and homework. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 4 The SOUND OF TELEVISION STATIC leaks as the CAMERA moves the last bedroom. ROBBIE FREELING is just a seven-year-ol lump under the covers. With the sheets tucked around him, looks like a ghost and where his head should be there is Dodgers baseball cap. The closet light is on and the clos opened only a crack to let in the safe night light as we beyond Robbie to CAROL ANNE FREELING. The STATIC SOUNDS f the 0.S. TV seem to arouse this pert six-years-old froma sound and regular sleep. Her eyes snap open. She listens flicks some sleep from her eyes, and rises out of bed.  CAMERA TRACKS AHEAD OF HER as if drawing her OUTSIDE the safety of her bedroom and roommate brother.

The STATIC crackles louder and a BLUE GLOW dawns across C Anne. She could be sleepwalking. Her eyes are riveted and breathing quickens. The STATIC BOOMS now and Carol Anne s at the TV set in front of her sleeping dad. She stares in the white snow, trying to see beyond the color dots. Caro Anne opens her mouth until we are certain she is going to SCREAM. Then
Hello! Hell-ooo! What do you want Hello! who are you! Hell-ooooo!
His eyes open.
Diane starts and sits up quickly.
Who are you!! Hey! INT. DANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 7 She is already swinging her legs out of bed and moving in the hallway.
I can’t hear you! INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 8 Robbie looks over to see Carol Anne’s bed empty.
The entire family gathers and watches their youngest chil yelling through the static at 2:35 in the morning.
What do you look like! Hello! Can I see you?  10

Anyone outside of Manhattan is familiar with this setting Sunday in suburbia. A neighbor mows his lawn, another was his car, and a group of kids play soccer in the street. T middle America World War II bought and paid for.

Then; an irregular glitch to this setting. A man, JEFF SH is running as furiously as his jelly-bowl paunch will all In his arms, a large brown shopping bag. Barely avoiding collision with the paper boy, he cuts across the lawn, jiggling the lettering. He crashes into the front door, finding it locked. He turns and runs around back, just as Steve opens the front door.
Shaw blasts past Dana, dressed in a terrycloth robe. She eating potato salad right out of the bowl in front of the refrigerator.
Jesus H. Christ!

Shaw almost loses his footing turning into this room. His breath exploding in wheezing puffs. He falls into a chair next to Steve Freeling and FIVE OTHER MALE NEIGHBORS who into the brown shopping bag, surfacing with Michelob Lite

Haden fumbled!
Sacked! !

Shhhhhhhh! ! INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - DAY 13 Diane is straightening things in here when she notices something that causes her to sadly catch her breath. She walks forward to the bird cage slowly letting it out. Car Anne’s yellow canary is feet up on the bottom of the cage

Oh Tweety, couldn’t you wait for a school day? EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 14 Robbie is next to a tall, misshapen oak tree that has gro bent forward, a little too close to the house. Robbie is marching in circles around the tree, acting brave. He sta to climb.
The Sunday FOOTBALL CROWD is on its feet. Haden has the b again and the pass is a “bomb”.
Look at that fuckin’ Dennard run.
Lester Hayes. Fuckin’ Hayes is there!! He’s there! He’s... The channel changes all by itself to Mister Rogers.
(yelling at the wall) Tuthill--! You asshole!
Turn it back! Christ!

Sorry guys. When my neighbor uses his remote... he’s on my same frequency. Steve turns it back to football. A second later, “Mr. Rodgers” is singing. Steve walks over to the wall, and po his remote control and fires!  16 17 18 19 From the other side of the wall comes a muffled ROAR.. Th voice of BEN TUTHILL.
Don’t start, Freeling!
Steve opens the sliding glass door and yells over the fen Tuthill, a robust man in a tank top and sunglasses, yells his window, the remote control brandished in Steve’s direction.
We got a game going on over here!
The kids wanna watch Mr. Rodgers!
I don’t care what you’re watching, as long as you show a little mercy with that thing!
(closing his window hard) Move your set!
Move yours! Tuthill clicks at Steve through his window.
Steve’s channels change and the gathering SCREAMS again.
Steve fires his remote at the Tuthills and a muffled “goddammit!” is heard.

Diane has Tweety by his little claw feet at arms length. a sour grimace she moves into the bathroom and raises the toilet seat, aims Tweety and... Carol Anne steps into the doorway catching her Mom red-handed.  20
Tweety--!!
(barely audible) Oh shit. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 20 With his own bedroom window facing him, Robbie climbs amo the twisted branches, then looks at the neighborhood and sky beyond.
Storm clouds are gathering in the distance.
Diane places little Tweety into the cigar box. She starts close the lid.
Tweety doesn’t like that smell.
Sweetheart, Tweety can’t smell a thing.

(giving orders) Put a flower with him. Diane smiles at this thought and takes a red rose from th vase on the windowsill. Carol Anne pulls into her pocket takes out some red licorice. She bites off the end, spits out into her hand and places the wet piece inside the cig box.
For when he’s hungry. She places a Polaroid snapshot of herself and Robbie.
For when he’s lonely. She covers him with a napkin.  22

For when it’s nighttime. Carol Anne starts to cry as she closes the lid. Diane loo on. She really loves this kid. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 22 Diane has dug a hole in the dirt. Robbie and Dana watch a Carol Anne places the cigar box into the earth. Dana is eating celery and Diane throws her a “you’re chewing too loud” look. Robbie, from up in the tree, watches fascinat as Diane and Carol Anne refill the hole. In the backgroun the football game is winding up with loud interludes betw the time-outs of the final quarter
Now I lay me down to sleep, I pray the Lord my soul to keep...
(rolls her eyes) Brother...
(to Dana) Stifle it!
If I should die before I wake...
(a defiant whisper) It did.
I pray the Lord my soul to take.
That was lovely, honey.
(staring at the freshly dug earth, calls down from the tree) Mom, when it rots can we dig it up and see the bones?
Robbie! !  23
(brightening-- a new topic) Can I get a goldfish now?! INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 23

Carol Anne stares wondrously as two brand new goldfish ni Hertz Mountain from the surface. Robbie sits on his bed i his PJ's reading a Popeye comic. Distant THUNDER can be h as Robbie looks over at his window. ROBBIE’S POV A weak flash of lightning outlines the tree he was playin earlier. It is not merely the overactive imagination of a nine-year-old that makes this tree scary to us. The twist branches that seem to suggest arms and the split trunk th appears to suggest horns is all too real even at first glance.
He doesn’t want to look. He doesn’t want to scare himself But he does.
Honey, you’re overfeeding them.
Tweety-two and Tweety-three wants seconds.
Mom, there’s a big storm headed this way.
You’11 be asleep by the time it gets here... if you hurry. Lights out! The kids dive for the covers. Diane turns out the light. room is overwhelmed by darkness. Carol Anne speaks up fir  24
(rapidly) Closet light! Closet light

My fault. My fault. Diane turns on the light in their closet and cracks open door. Carol Anne relaxes and waves good-night to her fish Robbie looks over at the rocking chair by the bureau. Sit straight up is clown doll. It is almost the size of Robbi Its stare is devilish and its smile is just a little too broad for comedy. Robbie gets up and without looking at the doll, throws a plaid shirt over its head. He climbs back into bed, outli by a blue flash from the window.

Two hands lift it from the shadows and into the light. Th lid starts to open and just as we expect to see Tweety-on see the “stash” instead. Steve removes a lid of grass and some zigzag papers and starts to roll a joint. On the TV an old MGM movie. Diane is reading Carl Jung’s MAN AND HIS SYMBOLS. Steve p up a brochure on pool equipment and diving boards.

(taking a hit) Sleepwalking. Sleepwalking. Nocturnal Somnambulism. * I’11 betcha it’s genetic. Carol Anne all last week and then last night. Me when I was ten. I once walked four blocks and fell asleep in the back seat of this man’s car. He went all the way to work before discovering me. God. I started screaming... people ran over. The police came. They took the guy downtown. My father had me examined for bruises hickeys, I don’t know. Oh shit, Steven! If we dig the pool and Carol Anne falls in before there’s any water... Steven... are you listening?  10. Steven takes the joint back from Diane and pulls it down halfway in one breath -- holding the hit
(he talks like Dennis Hopper ) Ever go off a three meter board?
What’s three meters?
About ten feet.
Honey, why don’t we just build the pool closer to the house and let he kids jump off the roof? ct
See, it’s like an air pocket. From three meters you’re free-falling. You can maybe squeeze in a half- gainer, jackknife into a swan twist back, tuck, splash.
Splat!!
Spashhh.
Splurg.
Honey, we can afford it.
We don’t really need it.
It’s great for business. We build the first house. We install the first pool. Look around us. By summer (in bass baritone) “the hills are alive with the smell of chlorine”.
Yeah and, our pool will be alive with a thousand guests.  25 11.
I’m the wind and you’re the feather!
INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 25 Steven flops Robbie onto his pillow just as a flash light the room and the tree outside the window. Carol Anne lies awake, watching.
I don’t like the tree, Dad.
It’s an old tree. It was here for a long time. Long before my company built this neighborhood.
I don’t like its arms. It knows I live here, doesn’t it?
(not aware this scares Robbie) It knows everything about us. That’s why I built our home next to it. So it could protect you and Carol Anne, Dana, your mom and me. It’s a wise old tree.
It looks at me. It knows I live here. Robbie is visibly frightened now and Steven realizes he’s scared him. Just then a tremor of thunder rolls through t bedroom and Robbie snuggles up to his dad.
Storm’s gonna miss us.
How do you know?
Because I can count. Then more thunder. Robbie flinches, but tries to be brave  26 12.
After you see the lightning, count until you hear the thunder. If you can count higher each time, that means the storm is moving away from you. A flash of lightning is seen.
Now count with me.
One, two, three... Thunder is HEARD.
Next time you’ll be able to count to four or more. You try it, okay?
Okay. Steven exits leaving the door open. Lightning occurs. Ste waits by the partially open door and listens as Robbie counts.

(very worried) One... two... three... four... five... Distant thunder is HEARD. Robbie is more relieved. INT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE DANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 26 He feels real good about himself. He KNOCKS on Dana’s doo Music is HEARD. The door opens.
Goodnight, Dana.
Uh, goodnight, Dad. (a beat, then)
Get off the phone, Dana.  27 28
(caught ) Okay, Dad. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 27 Robbie looks out the window. The tree stands there in the wind. Another flash of lightning, Robbie controls his fea and concentrates.

One, two... CRACK! BOOM! An explosive jolt of thunder rocks the house The closet light goes out as the tree outside the window suddenly bends forward as if looking in. Robbie sits bolt upright. Carol Anne wakes up SCREAMING.
Carol Anne and Robbie are asleep next to Diane and Steve. TV has been left on and the National Anthem starts to pla
Various positions, asleep.

The pre-recorded voice of the station manager signs off. beat... Transmission ceases and the soft roar of dead air fills the room as the static white snow colors the walls making shadows flicker and warp. It is only now that we first hear it. A SOUND intermingli with the TV hiss, like a bad connection from far, far awa whisper. Not one, but hundreds of them. They say nothing. It’s a chorus, tonal and inviting.
She turns on her side. And her eyes open surreally. Ever slowly, she turns her head fully facing the TV. Carol Ann smiles. A smile much too sophisticated for a five-years-o child.
The snow mixes with new imagery. Forms. Vague but luminou Always mingling. Impressionistic. Never hard-lined.

(whispering) Come out... come out... The picture tube starts to SNAP! Little flashes momentari blind Carol Anne. She blinks and tries to see deeper. SNA CRACK! It’s as if flashbulbs were being emitted. Steven a Diane turn fitfully but remain asleep. FLASH! POP! Robbie close to waking.

Smiling, on her knees now... she reaches out toward the T screen when... SOMETHING REACHES BACK. A Substance. A for like a wispy, smoky tentacle twists forward, EXTENDING FR THE PICTURE TUBE and snaking into the Freeling bedroom. Transparent and cold, it gives birth to itself, builds up its own energy, growing brighter as it seems to hover abo Carol Anne, then tower over the family asleep in the king sized bed.

She must bend her neck to look all the way up at the ceil where this cyclonic shape waltzes... studying.. at the ro then Carol Anne... AN EXPLOSION from the TV set. The brightest flash yet experienced. A force that expels the intruder from the se and into the room. Catapulting it past the family and int the wall RIGHT OVER THE BED, where it leaves a dark penci dot stain. The entire room shakes and the family is awake panicked. The window cracks, the curtain rod slips. Books and memen fall from the open hutch. The medicine cabinet opens and prescription medicine splatters on the tiled floor. The r lights flare then die. Every picture topples from the wal Just as quickly as it began, the episode ceases. A HUSH 2 descends. Everyone looks at Carol Anne. Carol Anne looks everyone... then intones, almost matter-of-factly.
They’re here.  29 30 15. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 29
A work glove shifts.
A steel-toed workboot slowly withdraws.

Lurch forward, dripping sod and wet grass. The shovel of the bulldozer touches the earth and scrapes deep swathe. CAMERA MOVES CLOSER as the cigar box coffin is cruelly exhumed in the ever-growing tidal wave of back yard turf.

Steve is on the phone, nervously smoking a cigarette as t bulldozer can be seen out the window, digging the new poo Diane is serving waffles around the breakfast table. E. B sits at Robbie’s feet, watching the waffles hopefully. On Carol Anne seems to have an appetite.
(on the phone) I’m not kidding, Jeff. How could anyone sleep through a six-point- five. Yes, damage. Stuff’s in pieces all over our bedroom.
(quietly to Carol Anne) Chew each bite ten times. Carol Anne exaggerates her chewing; smiling with her mout full.

I know that... we’ve had the radio on and there’s nothing about it. (after a beat) After the Sylmar quake it was two years before real estate was on the rise.  16. Diane is gently coaxing some information out of Carol Ann who mostly has her mouth full of waffles and blueberries.
When you said, “They’re here” last night.
Can I take my goldfish to school?
Maybe the fault line runs just under our house. Wouldn’t that be a scream?
The ceiling got crumbs all over my bed.
(to Carol Anne) Sweetheart. Do you remember last night? Do you remember when you woke up and said, “They’re here?”
Uh huh.
Who did you mean? Who’s here?
(mouth full) The TV people.
She’s stoned.
What do you know about it?

More’n you. Ask Dad. Robbie picks up his milk to take a sip when the bottom of glass drops out, the milk splashing back onto Robbie’s ce bowl, overflowing cereal all over the table and onto Dana blouse in a burst, perhaps slightly strong for the small amount of spilled milk
(throwing up his hands) It’s not my mess.
(jumps up from the table) Thanks a lot, jerko - I’ve got class in twenty minutes.
Mom.

Gimme that thing before you cut yourself. Carol Anne has a big dripping splash of milk running down forehead. Oblivious to this she just keeps eating, goes o to the kitchen TV... turns it on to the “Today Show”, the switches to an “in between” channel and watches the snow.
I’m outta here! See ya early.
(imitating Dad) I’m outta here!
(pushing him back) You I can handle.
I got school!!
Breakfast first.

(casually) All right, I’1l just flunk. Robbie shrugs, reaches for his spoon to resume eating and notices something unusual. The spoon is bent. He looks ar the table. Every spoon is bent. Shrugging it off, Robbie lifts his cereal bowl and drinks right out of it, two tin trails dripping off his chin, spotting his school shirt.  31 32 33 18. EXT. FREELING’S BACK YARD - DAY 31 A big man, PUGSLEY, thirties, bald, steps out of his pool install action truck wearing combat boots, a Teamster T- shirt, mirrored sunglasses and a baseball cap turned arou backwards on his head. He motions to the bulldozer driver “take a gander”. Dana grabs her bike and rides off. The workmen pause to stare at her. Pugsley and the dozer driv share a salacious grin and the dozer driver pops his clut rapidly, the dozer lurching suggestively several times.

Diane has witnessed this sloppy display through the open door. Choosing to pass over it, she turns toward the kitc table to clean up. E. BUZZ, the dog, is sitting on a pull out chair eating from everyone’s plates. Diane sighs and shoos E. Buzz away.
When you leave the table, Carol Anne... Robbie, you push your chairs in. Carol Anne is trying to fine-tune the snow on television.
Aw, honey you’re going to ruin your eyes. This is not good for you. She turns the set to another channel where a WAR MOVIE is showing. Soldiers blowing up and screaming.

Diane is cleaning up. Broken glass surrounds her. She cup her left hand and picks narrow shards out of the shag whe the GROWLING begins. Diane turns and sees... DIANE’S POV E. BUZZ is growling at the wall. Looking up at something don’t see. Diane sidesteps the broken vases to follow E. Buzz’s eyeline right up the wall and onto the stain.
She cocks her head curiously.

It has grown since this morning. Like a Rorschach pattern Diane tries to rub it out with a pillowcase. She slips in the bathroom and wets one corner, then returns when... Diane stops. Carefully, she watches E. Buzz, who has ceas growling.

Diane enters, sees Pugsley drinking a cup of coffee from of her China cups.

In a disconcerting jump, all of the furniture, Carol Anne Diane disappear. The basic structure of the kitchen remai exactly the same for this is a model home somewhere in Cu Verde Estates. Our construction standards are very liberal. Matter of fact, a neighbor of mine put a jacuzzi in his bedroom, with a running aqueduct connecting it to the wading pool outside which he built half in half out of his living room. That home was featured in last month’s issue of Town and Country.

37 38 22. Sparse lightning over the mountains as the storm clouds b to roll in. The neighborhood is quiet. Warm window light spill is out across the well manicured lawns. Three empty trashcans block the drive... Steve groans as parks half on, half off the curb, climbs out, and starts removing obstacles when from nowhere Diane is there, literally pulling toward the house.
Hey babe. Guess who just bought L-J 237...

Leave it. Quick, before it stops again.
We have never seen Diane focused and again so frazzled. H words are coming in spurts. She must constantly catch her breath. The thrill in her voice is backed up against an oppressive fear.

Okay, okay... look. Okay. Listen. I’ve kept Dana and Robbie out of this, but Carol Anne was with me when it started so I cut her in, but Dana would blab and Robbie’d be up for three weeks sleeping on your side of the bed.  23.

No, goddammit, you sit down! I mean... stand right there. And just... just have an open mind. Reach back into our past when I used to know you with one and use it for the next coupla minutes. Carol Anne suddenly appears from around the corner lookin exhausted and cranky. In her hand is a San Diego Charger football helmet.
Mommy didn’t cook any dinner.
(loud) We’ll go to Pizza Hut, all right?

Looking around he sees chalk marks all over the kitchen floor. Arrows and squares and numbers in two colors. Diane’s breathing quickens as she steadies herself. Diane places each leg in one of the proscribed circles and looks up at Steve.

(last words) Okay... okay now, watch!! Watch!! She removes her hands from the back of the chair and step aside. Steve watches Diane as much as the chair. He start step forward when Diane throws both of her hands out to s him.

Look! The chair begins to tremble. It virtually jitterbugs in place... then begins to move forward picking up speed unt it traverses the entire length of the kitchen ending up r in front of Steve’s bullfrog eyes.
Yawning.
With hysterical victory in her eyes.
Looking for wires. He kneels and feels the chair legs, th immediately looks to Diane for the answer.

Don’t argue! ! Carol Anne shrugs and puts on the football helmet. Diane over to Steve’s side and pushes the chair out of the way. Carol Anne sits on the floor in a circle with her name on in yellow chalk.
Starts to run for her protectively. Diane restrains him.
She starts to tremble as if on a funhouse ride. Her littl body begins to move forward, faster, and all the way acro the kitchen floor right into Diane’s arms.
(rubbing her fanny) That burned!

You can’t believe the feeling.

Not from inside the house. Maybe Tuthill got himself a super remote from the Radio Shack. Carol Anne adjusts her helmet and sits inside her launch circle. Diane and Steve are having the discussion across room and aren’t aware of her.

Okay. I have a plan. I have a plan. Something’s occurring here that we can’t explain. If Carol Anne wasn’t wearing that helmet...

Right. Okay. Let’s wake the kids. No big deal! Let’s wake them, spend tonight at the Travel Lodge in Broxton. And come back tomorrow with experts! Experts who can tell us what it is that’s happening and if it’s safe to go home.
